senses.definition: a request, an order or a demand for somebody to do something or to go somewhere

senses.definition: a demand or pressure placed on somebody/something

senses.definition: a strong feeling of attraction that a particular place has for you

senses.definition: a player’s bid or turn to bid

senses.definition: to a higher standard or level than is required for a job or task

senses.definition: to suddenly feel a strong need to go to the toilet
to be put at a disadvantage

in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant

senses.definition: to start to be able to breathe normally again after running or doing exercise that makes you tired
to become ill with a cold

senses.definition: to catch a very bad cold

senses.definition: to attract or please somebody

senses.definition: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something

senses.definition: to get an advantage over somebody by doing something when they are not expecting it and not ready for it

senses.definition: to make somebody surprised and no longer calm

senses.definition: a group of shops or hotels owned by the same company
examples: a supermarket/hotel/retail chain
chain of something a chain of stores/shops/restaurants
a chain of department stores
a chain of clothes shops

senses.definition: a thing that limits somebody’s freedom or ability to do something
examples: the chains of fear/misery

senses.definition: a situation in which a number of people selling and buying houses must each complete the sale of their house before buying from the next person
a problem that prevents you from doing what you would like to do
examples: The responsibility was a ball and chain around my ankle.

senses.definition: one of the stages in a process or a line of argument
examples: Food production, processing and marketing are different links in the chain from farmer to consumer.

senses.definition: the point at which a system or an organization is most likely to fail
examples: She went straight for the one weak link in the chain of his argument.

senses.definition: to fasten something with a chain; to fasten somebody/something to another person or thing with a chain, so that they do not escape or get stolen
examples: chain somebody/something The doors were always locked and chained.
They maintained that the convicts working on the roads were never chained.
He was beaten in his cell while in handcuffs and with his legs chained.
chain somebody/something up The dog was chained up for the night.

chain somebody/something to somebody/something She chained her bicycle to the gate.
Four activists chained themselves to construction equipment.
(figurative) I've been chained to my desk all week (= because there was so much work).
chain somebody/something together The detainees were chained together in groups of two or three.

senses.definition: a piece of furniture for one person to sit on, with a back, a seat and four legs
examples: a table and chairs
on a chair Sit on your chair!
in a chair an old man asleep in a chair (= an armchair)

He sighed and leaned back in his chair.
‘Sit down,’ she said, pointing to the empty chair next to her.
a comfortable chair
a wooden/leather/plastic chair
a folding/reclining/swivel chair
an office/a desk chair
‘Please, be my guest.’ He gestured towards an empty chair.
A cat was asleep on the chair.
His tall figure was slumped in his chair.
Rising slowly from his chair he went to a bookcase.
A chair stood facing the window.
Come in and take a chair (= sit down).
She gave me her chair.
She got up from her chair to address the meeting.
He lay back in the reclining chair and went to sleep.
I gestured to an empty chair.
He pulled out a chair for me.
She pushed back her chair and got to her feet.
He put his feet up on the desk and lay back in his chair.
She sank into her chair and opened the letter.
He sat nervously on the edge of his chair.
She was shifting about uneasily in her chair.
Lisa heard a chair scraping the floor.
a set of antique dining chairs
a dining table and four matching chairs
They straightened in their chairs when the manager burst in.
The chair creaked every time I moved.
She tipped her chair back and fixed her gaze full upon him.
I swivelled round in my chair and picked up my phone.
She leaned back in her chair and yawned.
He gripped the arm of his chair as she spoke.
I dropped my bags and flopped down into the nearest chair.
She returned to the swivel chair (= one on which the seat turns around without moving the base) behind her desk.
He always swivels around in his chair.
dining/​kitchen chairs

senses.definition: the position of being in charge of a meeting or committee; the person who holds this position
examples: in the chair Who is in the chair today?

chair of something the chair of the committee

senses.definition: the position of being in charge of a department in a university; a special position as a university professor
examples: He holds the chair of philosophy at Oxford.
the department chair

senses.definition: (especially in the US) a chair in which criminals are killed by having a powerful electric current passed through their bodies; the method of execution that uses this chair
to act as the chairman or chairwoman of a meeting, discussion, etc.
examples: to chair a committee
Who's chairing the meeting?
a judging panel chaired by a radio presenter.
I had the unenviable task of chairing the closing session.
Lord Stansfield will chair the committee.

senses.definition: the person in charge of a meeting, who tells people when they can speak, etc.
examples: Sir Herbert took it upon himself to act as chairman.
The motion was carried on the casting vote of the chairman.

senses.definition: the person in charge of a committee, a company, etc.
examples: the vice/deputy chairman
the committee/board/party/club chairman
the chairman of the committee/board/party/club
the executive chairman

The chairman of the company presented the annual report.

the chairman of the board of governors (= of a school)

a report by the outgoing chairman
chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee

senses.definition: a new or difficult task that tests somebody’s ability and skill
examples: a tough/major/significant challenge

Destruction of the environment is one of the most serious challenges we face.

challenge of something Countries need to work together to address the challenge of climate change.

challenge of doing something The gallery has risen to the challenge of exhibiting the works of young artists.
challenge for somebody/something The challenge for the government is to find a way of providing affordable housing.
challenge to somebody/something Digital piracy continues to pose huge challenges to the industry.

the challenges facing nurses in casualty

senses.definition: an invitation or a suggestion to somebody that they should enter a competition, fight, etc.
examples: She accepted his challenge to a debate on the issue.
I'm looking forward to taking on the challenge.
challenge for something He plans to mount a challenge for the party leadership.
She took up his challenge.
plans to mount a leadership challenge within the party
his title challenge to the heavyweight champion
a challenge from the other political party
I accepted his challenge to a game of chess.

senses.definition: a statement or an action that shows that somebody refuses to accept something and questions whether it is right, legal, etc.
examples: Their legal challenge was unsuccessful.
challenge to something It was a direct challenge to the president's authority.
challenge from somebody The commission reconsidered the rules after a challenge from the television networks.
The demonstration represents a direct challenge to the new law.
a legal challenge to the President's power

senses.definition: to question whether a statement or an action is right, legal, etc.; to refuse to accept something
examples: challenge something His legal team immediately sought to challenge the decision.
The story was completely untrue and was successfully challenged in court.
She does not like anyone challenging her authority.
This discovery challenges traditional beliefs.
The new study challenges fundamental assumptions about the virus.
challenge somebody on something She challenged him on his old-fashioned views.
challenge somebody He repeated the claim but the interviewer did not challenge him.

Others maintain that there is a significant deterioration in quality in his post-war work.
Picasso himself claimed that good art is created, but great art is stolen.

As the author points out, Picasso borrowed imagery from African art.

It has been suggested that Picasso’s painting was influenced by jazz music.
Harley sought to challenge the jurisdiction of the court.

senses.definition: to invite somebody to enter a competition, fight, etc.; to suggest strongly that somebody should do something (especially when you think that they might be unwilling to do it)
examples: challenge somebody to something Mike challenged me to a game of chess.
The count challenged him to a duel.
challenge somebody to do something The opposition leader challenged the prime minister to call an election.

senses.definition: to enter into a competition against somebody to achieve something or take something from them
examples: challenge for something She was poised to challenge for the party leadership.
challenge somebody for something He challenged her for the role of leader.
challenge somebody She is the person most likely to challenge him before the next election.

senses.definition: to test somebody’s/your ability and skills, especially in an interesting way
examples: challenge somebody The job doesn't really challenge her.

challenge yourself She continues to challenge herself as a dancer.

senses.definition: to order somebody to stop and say who they are or what they are doing
examples: We were challenged by police at the border.

senses.definition: a person, team, etc. that has won a competition, especially in a sport
examples: the world/European/national/Olympic champion
the defending champion (= the person who was champion the last time and is trying to be champion again)
the reigning champion (= the person who is champion now)
the world basketball champions

a former Italian champion jockey

senses.definition: a person who fights for, or speaks in support of, a group of people or a belief
examples: She was a long-term champion of animal rights and environmental protection.

senses.definition: a possibility of something happening, especially something that you want
examples: chance of doing something She only has a slim chance of passing the exam.

chance that… There's a good chance that I'll be back in time.

the variety with the best chance for success

senses.definition: a suitable time or situation when you have the opportunity to do something

senses.definition: an unpleasant or dangerous possibility
examples: When installing electrical equipment don't take any chances. A mistake could kill.

chance on somebody/something The producers didn't want to take a chance on an unknown actor.
chance with somebody/something The police were taking no chances with the protesters.

senses.definition: the way that some things happen without any cause that you can see or understand
examples: I met her by chance (= without planning to) at the airport.

It was pure chance that we were both there.
We'll plan everything very carefully and leave nothing to chance.

senses.definition: happening in a way that was lucky, although it was not planned

senses.definition: to have the possibility of succeeding or achieving something
examples: ‘Do you think we'll win?’ ‘I think we're in with a chance.’

senses.definition: used especially in questions, to ask whether something is true, possible, etc.
examples: Are you in love with him, by any chance?

senses.definition: it is likely that…
examples: The chances are you won't have to pay.

senses.definition: a small chance of being successful if a great effort is made
examples: We still have a fighting chance of beating them and winning the Cup.

senses.definition: to give somebody/something some opportunity to do something
examples: That dog will give you a nasty bite, given half a chance.

senses.definition: to be equally likely to do or not do something
examples: She has more than an even chance of winning tomorrow.

senses.definition: there is no possibility
examples: ‘Do you think he'll do it?’ ‘No chance.’

senses.definition: to have no chance at all
to have no chance at all
examples: He hasn't a dog's chance of passing the exam.

senses.definition: to have no chance at all
examples: There isn't a snowball's chance in hell that I'll wear that thing!

senses.definition: because of the possibility of something happening, although it is unlikely
examples: I didn't think you'd be at home but I just called by on the off chance.

senses.definition: a reasonable chance of success
to have the possibility of succeeding or achieving something
examples: The driver didn't stand a chance of stopping in time.

senses.definition: to decide to do something, knowing that it might be the wrong choice
examples: We took a chance on the weather and planned to have the party outside.

senses.definition: to take a risk or to use the opportunities that you have and hope that things will happen in the way that you want

senses.definition: with the hope of using a particular situation in order to gain some advantage for yourself
the act or result of something becoming different

a change in policy/law

social/political/economic change

senses.definition: the process of replacing something with something new or different; a thing that is used to replace something
examples: change of something a change of address
a change of government

senses.definition: the fact of a situation, a place or an experience being different from what is usual and therefore likely to be interesting, fun, etc.

a change from something The manual work made a welcome change from his previous job.

senses.definition: the money that you get back when you have paid for something giving more money than the amount it costs
examples: Don't forget your change!
That's 40p change.
The ticket machine gives change.
This machine does not give change.
The meal left me with not much change from $200.

I checked my change before leaving the store.

senses.definition: coins rather than paper money
examples: Do you have any change for the machine?
in change I have two dollars in change (= coins that together are worth two dollars).
I didn't have any small change (= coins of low value) to leave as a tip.
He puts his loose change in a money box for the children.
change for something Could you give me change for a ten pound note (= coins or notes that are worth this amount)?
I counted the money carefully.
Where can I change my money into dollars?
paper money (= money that is made of paper, not coins)
How much cash do you have on you?
Payments can be made by cheque or in cash.
The ticket machine doesn’t give change.
I don’t have any small change (= coins of low value).
I've got about 25 dollars in change.
I had around £25 in change.
He emptied his pockets of loose change.
Ask the cashier if she has change for €20.

senses.definition: an extra set of clothes, etc.
examples: She packed a change of clothes for the weekend.
I keep a change of shoes in the car.

senses.definition: an occasion when you go from one bus, train or plane to another during a journey
examples: The journey involved three changes.

senses.definition: the menopause (= the time during which a woman gradually stops menstruating, usually at around the age of 50)
a person, thing, situation, etc. that is better/worse than the previous or present one
examples: Voters see the new leader as a change for the better.
I reckon we've all made a big change for the better.
His family had detected a change for the worse in his behaviour.

senses.definition: if you have a change of heart, your attitude towards something changes, usually making you feel more friendly, helpful, etc.
examples: Dan did not want to get married but recently he’s had a change of heart.
She said she's not coming, but she might have a change of heart.

senses.definition: an act of changing what you think about a situation, etc.
to get no help or information from somebody
examples: We got no change out of the legal department.

senses.definition: to make changes to something in order to have greater variety
examples: Ring the changes with a new colour.

senses.definition: an event or a series of events that has started to happen and will cause important changes or results
examples: A wind of change was blowing through the banking world.

senses.definition: to become different
examples: Rick hasn't changed. He looks exactly the same as he did at school.

Things have changed dramatically since then.
Her life changed completely when she won the lottery.
change with something My attitude to life has changed with age.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something different
examples: Fame hasn't really changed him.

senses.definition: to pass from one state or form into another; to make somebody/something pass from one state or form into another
examples: Wait for the traffic lights to change.

change to/into something The lights changed to green.

change A to/into B With a wave of her magic wand, she changed the frog into a handsome prince.

senses.definition: to stop having one state, position or direction and start having another

senses.definition: to replace one thing, person, service, etc. with something new or different

senses.definition: to exchange positions, places, etc. with somebody else, so that you have what they have, and they have what you have

senses.definition: to exchange money into the money of another country

change A into B to change dollars into yen

senses.definition: to exchange money for the same amount in different coins or notes

senses.definition: to go from one bus, train, etc. to another in order to continue a journey

change something I stopped in Moscow only to change planes.

senses.definition: to put on different or clean clothes
examples: I went into the bedroom to change.

(especially British English) I didn't have time to get changed before the party (= to put different clothes on).

senses.definition: to put clean clothes or a clean nappy on a baby
examples: She can't even change a nappy.

senses.definition: to put clean sheets, etc. on a bed
examples: to change the sheets

senses.definition: to pass to a different owner

senses.definition: to change to a different or new activity while you are in the middle of something else; to change from supporting one person or thing to another
to change a decision or an opinion
examples: Nothing will make me change my mind.

senses.definition: to be in somebody else’s situation
examples: I'm perfectly happy—I wouldn't change places with anyone.

senses.definition: to express a different opinion or behave in a different way when your situation changes
examples: Wait until it happens to him—he'll soon change his tune.

senses.definition: to start to live or behave in a different way from before
examples: He was in trouble with the police as a teenager but now he’s completely changed his ways.

senses.definition: to keep changing your mind or what you are doing
people cannot change their character, especially if they have a bad character
examples: You didn’t really expect her to be on time, did you? A leopard can’t change its spots.

senses.definition: a television station
examples: a television/TV channel
cable/digital/satellite channels
a news channel
a music/sports/movie channel
to change/switch channels
on a channel What's on Channel 4 tonight?

One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the phone or on social networking websites.
Compared to the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the phone.
On average the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.

When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

senses.definition: to be similar to somebody/something else, either better or worse
examples: This school compares with the best in the country (= it is as good as them).

senses.definition: an occasion when two or more people or things are compared
examples: The films are too different for a fair comparison.
comparison of A and B a comparison of the rail systems in Britain and France
comparison of A with B a comparison of men’s salaries with those of women
comparison between A and B comparisons between Britain and the rest of Europe
comparison of A to B a comparison of the brain to a computer (= showing what is similar)
comparison with somebody/something It is difficult to make a comparison with her previous book—they are completely different.
You can draw comparisons with the situation in Ireland (= say how the two situations are similar).
There is no published information that would allow a direct comparison with other regions or countries.
This chart provides a comparison of the ways that teenage boys and girls in the UK spend their free time.
In many cases, the results for boys and girls are virtually the same/identical.
In many cases, the results for boys are virtually the same as/identical to the results for girls.
Both boys and girls spend the bulk of their free time with friends.
Most of the boys do more than two hours of sport a week, as do many of the girls.
Like many of the girls, most of the boys spend a large part of their free time using the internet.
The girls particularly enjoy using social networking websites. Similarly, nearly all the boys said they spent at least two to three hours a week on these sites.
a comparison with other schools
a comparison of unemployment rates over the past 15 years
a comparison between figures for last year and this year

senses.definition: used especially at the beginning of a sentence when the next thing that is mentioned is compared with something in the previous sentence
examples: By comparison, expenditure on education increased last year.
His problems seemed trivial by comparison.

senses.definition: when compared with somebody/something
examples: The second half of the game was dull by comparison with the first.
The tallest buildings in London are small in comparison with New York's skyscrapers.
The glasses are small in comparison with the old ones.
Jane is still quite young, and Fiona seems old by comparison.

senses.definition: to seem less important when compared with something else
examples: Last year's riots pale in comparison with this latest outburst of violence.
Our problems pale into insignificance when compared to theirs.

senses.definition: used to emphasize the difference between two people or things that are being compared
examples: In terms of price there's no comparison (= one thing is much more expensive than the other).

senses.definition: to take part in a contest or game
examples: The games were an outstanding success, with almost 2 400 athletes competing.
compete in something He's hoping to compete in the London marathon.

compete against somebody They are competing against teams of full-time professional players.
compete for something He is expected to compete for the title of world champion next year.
He regularly competes in races.
They have what it takes to compete at the highest level of their sport.

senses.definition: to try to be more successful or better than somebody else who is trying to do the same as you
examples: They simply cannot compete in the international market.
compete for something Several companies are competing for the contract.

The result is more applicants competing for fewer jobs.
compete with somebody/something Small independent bookshops find it difficult to compete with the online stores.
compete against somebody/something For too long UK shipyards have been competing against each other.
compete on something We can't compete with them on price.
to compete on quality/cost
compete to do something There are too many magazines competing to attract readers.

a readiness to compete actively in the global system

senses.definition: an event in which people compete with each other to find out who is the best at something
examples: a design/an art/a talent competition
an international/a national competition

She's won a prestigious singing competition.
in a competition He won fourth place in the competition.
a competition to do something a competition to design the new Parliament building
There will be a painting competition for children of different age groups.
They twice won the European Cup, a knockout competition between the top teams in Europe.
I encouraged her to enter the essay competition.
wines that won medals at major wine competitions
a competition for the best chef
a competition between the best teams in the country
We're going to have a competition to see who can swim the fastest.
The competition is open to all readers of the magazine.
The American women dominated the competition, winning all the events.
I won the car in a competition.
She won an international dancing competition.

senses.definition: a situation in which people or organizations compete with each other for something that not everyone can have
examples: stiff/fierce/intense/tough competition
competition between A and B competition between two similar products
competition among somebody/something The government said the new laws would enhance competition among banks.
competition for something competition for resources/jobs/food, etc.
competition to do something competition to secure a place on the course
competition from somebody/something The firm is facing stiff competition from its online rivals.
in competition with somebody/something Public education is run in direct competition with the private sector.
in competition with somebody/something for something We are in competition with four other companies for the contract.
in competition with somebody/something to do something The programme puts two couples in competition with each other to redecorate one another's homes.
Competition is heating up and sales are shrinking.
We won the contract in the face of tough competition.
Fierce competition exists between schools in the area.
This is a significant achievement for the company in the face of stiff competition from its Australian rival.
Their rivalry had been one of friendly competition.
There is a lot of competition between rival airlines.
There is head-to-head competition in production and distribution.

This intensified the competition for the same investors' funds.

We face strong competition from other countries.
intense competition for the contract
policies aimed at fostering greater competition in the industry
to fight off competition from foreign firms
She plans to go into competition with her former employer.
The company is having to lay off workers in the face of stiff competition.

senses.definition: the people who are competing against somebody
examples: We'll be able to assess the competition at the conference.

senses.definition: used to describe a situation in which people or organizations compete against each other
examples: competitive games/sports
Graduates have to fight for jobs in an increasingly competitive market.
Those businesses are operating in an extremely competitive environment.
The company has succeeded in a highly competitive industry.
a fiercely competitive sport
A competitive approach to learning is discouraged.
It's a fiercely competitive market.
Japan's banks face daunting competitive pressures.

senses.definition: trying very hard to be better than others
examples: You have to be highly competitive to do well in sport these days.
a very competitive person

He has a strong competitive streak.
Her competitive nature often overshadows the other qualities in her game.

senses.definition: as good as or better than others
examples: a shop selling clothes at competitive prices (= as low as any other shop)
to gain a competitive advantage over rival companies
How do we maintain our competitive edge?
What is your strategy for helping the company stay competitive in a global market?
competitive with somebody/something We need to work harder to remain competitive with other companies.
We offer loans at competitive rates.

highly competitive prices
skills training to make our industries more competitive in world markets

senses.definition: a person who takes part in a competition
examples: Over 200 competitors entered the race.
the youngest competitor in the event
the most successful South African competitor at the games
competitor for something There are six remaining competitors for the grand prize of $50 000.
She is one of the sport's top competitors.

senses.definition: a person or an organization that competes against others, especially in business
examples: We produce cheaper goods than our competitors.

competitor to something They are set to become formidable competitors to American companies.
competitor for something Japan was not a major competitor for scarce resources such as oil.

fierce competitors for the dominant position in the Asian market

senses.definition: to say that you are annoyed, unhappy or not satisfied about somebody/something
examples: She never complains, but she's obviously exhausted.
(informal) ‘How are you?’ ‘Oh, I can't complain (= I'm all right).’
complain to somebody Annoyed residents have complained to the police.
complain about something Shoppers complained about the lack of toilet facilities.
complain to somebody about something I'm going to complain to the manager about this.
complain of something The defendant complained of intimidation during the investigation.

I’m going to complain to the manager about this.

All the guests complained about the noise.

I'm going to complain to the authorities about this!

senses.definition: a reason for not being satisfied; a statement that somebody makes saying that they are not satisfied
examples: a formal complaint

complaint of something The Tribunal upheld his complaint of discrimination.
complaint against somebody/something I believe you have a complaint against one of our nurses.

complaint from somebody Council bosses said they would respond to complaints from residents.

complaint (that…) a complaint that he had been unfairly treated

a complaint about working conditions
a complaint against the police
a complaint from a customer

complaints arising from late payment
to make a complaint to the authorities

senses.definition: the act of complaining
examples: I can see no grounds for complaint.

without complaint Workers were expected to accept pay cuts without complaint.

senses.definition: an illness, especially one that is not serious, and often one that affects a particular part of the body

senses.definition: including all the parts, etc. that are necessary; whole

senses.definition: finished

senses.definition: including something as an extra part or feature

senses.definition: to finish making or doing something

senses.definition: in every way possible; in every part

senses.definition: containing one main part (= the root of a word or main clause of a sentence) and one or more other parts (called affixes or subordinate clauses)

senses.definition: a group of buildings of a similar type together in one place

an industrial complex (= a site with many factories)

a leisure complex

a block of flats
the school’s science block

senses.definition: a group of things that are connected

senses.definition: a set of beliefs or fears, which may not be conscious, that can make somebody very unhappy or cause a mental illness

senses.definition: a feeling of worry or embarrassment about something that is not necessary or reasonable

senses.definition: made of many different things or parts that are connected; difficult to understand

computer software/graphics/hardware
a computer screen
a computer programmer/user

senses.definition: to give all your attention to something and not think about anything else
examples: I can't concentrate with all that noise going on.

concentrate on doing something He tried to concentrate on reading his book but couldn't.

senses.definition: to bring something together in one place

senses.definition: to increase the strength of a substance by reducing its volume, for example by boiling it
the ability to direct all your effort and attention on one thing, without thinking of other things
examples: This book requires a great deal of concentration.

senses.definition: the process of people directing effort and attention on a particular thing

senses.definition: a lot of something in one place

senses.definition: the amount of a substance in a liquid or in another substance

senses.definition: an idea or a principle that is connected with something abstract

senses.definition: worried and feeling concern about something/somebody
examples: Concerned citizens can have a huge impact.
concerned parents/residents/parents/locals
concerned about something/somebody The president is deeply concerned about this issue.

concerned for something/somebody He didn't seem in the least concerned for her safety.

senses.definition: affected by something; involved in something
examples: The loss was a tragedy for all concerned.
Where our children's education is concerned, no compromise is acceptable.
The individuals concerned have some explaining to do.
The meetings were often embarrassing for all concerned.
be concerned in something Everyone who was directly concerned in (= had some responsibility for) the incident has now resigned.

senses.definition: interested in something; dealing with something
examples: The public is increasingly concerned with how food is produced.
Mathematics is concerned essentially with understanding abstract concepts.
Social anthropology is centrally concerned with the diversity of culture.
You shouldn't be concerned with what they think.
The government seems more concerned with protecting businesses than with education.

senses.definition: to think it is important to do something
examples: She was concerned to write about situations that everybody could identify with.

senses.definition: used to give your personal opinion on something
examples: As far as I am concerned, you can do what you like.

senses.definition: used to give facts or an opinion about a particular aspect of something
examples: She's doing fine as far as French is concerned, it's her German I'm worried about.

senses.definition: a public performance of music
examples: to attend/go to a concert
The orchestra gave a concert in Miami in January.
a series of concerts organized by the Oxford Chamber Music Society
a classical/rock/pop concert
a benefit/charity concert
in concert They're in concert at Wembley arena.
at a concert They also performed at a concert in Rome last month.
concert of something a concert of music by Bach
concert by somebody/something I got dragged along to concerts by bands I hated.
concert for somebody/something a fundraising concert for tsunami victims
a concert hall
a concert pianist/tour/series
He will be giving his farewell concert as Music Director of the Ulster Orchestra.
She sang at a gala concert to celebrate the music of Stephen Sondheim.
The King attended a gala concert at the Royal Festival Hall.
The band is putting on its biggest concert of the year.
The orchestra performs its final concert of the season tomorrow.
We're organizing a concert for charity.
a concert of military music
They performed a concert of music by Rachmaninoff and Prokofiev.
We saw Raye in concert at Reading Festival.

senses.definition: working together with somebody/something
to decide or believe something as a result of what you have heard or seen
examples: conclude something It is too early for us to conclude anything.
conclude something from something What do you conclude from that?
conclude (that)… The report concluded (that) the cheapest option was to close the laboratory.
conclude from something that… He concluded from their remarks that they were not in favour of the plan.
it is concluded that… It was concluded that the level of change necessary would be low.
+ speech ‘So it should be safe to continue,’ he concluded.
In conclusion, the study has provided useful insights into the issues relating to people’s perception of crime.
On the basis of this study, it can be concluded that the introduction of new street lighting did not reduce reported crime.
To sum up, no evidence can be found to support the view that improved street lighting reduces reported crime.
The available evidence clearly leads to the conclusion that the media do have an influence on the public perception of crime.
The main conclusion to be drawn from this study is that public perception of crime is significantly influenced by crime news reporting.
This study has shown that people’s fear of crime is out of all proportion to crime itself.
Fear of crime is out of all proportion to the actual level of crime, and the reasons for this can be summarized as follows. First…
Overall/In general, women are more likely than men to feel insecure walking alone after dark.
‘There really isn't much hope left,’ she concluded.
It was concluded that there was little that could be done.
Whatever you conclude, remember that there are certain things we may not know.

senses.definition: to come to an end; to bring something to an end
examples: This was how the negotiations finally concluded.
Let me make just a few concluding remarks.
the concluding chapter of the book
conclude with something The programme concluded with Stravinsky's ‘Rite of Spring’.
conclude by doing something He concluded by wishing everyone a safe trip home.
conclude something The commission concluded its investigation last month.
And that concludes our programme for today.
The main responsibility of a salesperson is to conclude a sale successfully.
conclude something with something She concluded her speech with a quotation from Shakespeare.
conclude+ speech ‘Anyway, she should be back soon,’ he concluded.

senses.definition: to arrange and settle an agreement with somebody formally and finally
examples: They concluded a treaty with Turkey.
A trade agreement was concluded between the two countries.
The problems arose from the failure to conclude a new agreement.

senses.definition: something that you decide when you have thought about all the information connected with the situation
examples: We can safely draw some conclusions from our discussion.
He arrived at a different conclusion.
There is abundant evidence to support this conclusion.
Other studies have yielded the same conclusion.
The final section summarizes the conclusions of the study.
conclusion (that)… I've come to the conclusion that he's not the right person for the job.
New evidence might lead to the conclusion that we are wrong.
conclusion about/on somebody/something It is too soon to reach any conclusions about voting trends.
The present findings point to a similar conclusion.
It is difficult to base a definitive conclusion on their data.
He bases his conclusions on very limited research.
How did he reach this startling conclusion?
I can't draw any conclusions from what she said.
It all points to the conclusion that nobody knew what was going on.
It is difficult to draw any firm conclusions at such an early stage.
Only tentative conclusions can be drawn from these results.
The data he collected strengthened his conclusions.
This does not warrant the conclusion that he failed.
What did you base these conclusions on?

senses.definition: the end of something such as a speech or a piece of writing
examples: The conclusion of the book was disappointing.
After his death, his assistant completed chapters nine and ten and wrote the conclusion.
If we took this argument to its logical conclusion…
conclusion to something The film is a fitting conclusion to the series.
in conclusion In conclusion (= finally), I would like to thank…
In conclusion, the study has provided useful insights into the issues relating to people’s perception of crime.
On the basis of this study, it can be concluded that the introduction of new street lighting did not reduce reported crime.
To sum up, no evidence can be found to support the view that improved street lighting reduces reported crime.
The available evidence clearly leads to the conclusion that the media do have an influence on the public perception of crime.
The main conclusion to be drawn from this study is that public perception of crime is significantly influenced by crime news reporting.
This study has shown that people’s fear of crime is out of all proportion to crime itself.
Fear of crime is out of all proportion to the actual level of crime, and the reasons for this can be summarized as follows. First…
Overall/In general, women are more likely than men to feel insecure walking alone after dark.
The story's ultimate conclusion does not come as a surprise.
In conclusion, I would like to thank you all for your hard work.
This performance was a fitting conclusion to his career.
The meeting was brought to a hasty conclusion.

senses.definition: the formal and final arrangement of something official
examples: the successful conclusion of a trade treaty
I’m afraid we’re running out of time, so we'll have to make this the final question.
We've only got a couple of minutes left, so can we summarize what we've agreed?
I'd like to close the session with a few final remarks…
We'll have to leave it there, but thank you all very much for your input.
Well, that's all we have time for today, but we'll meet again on Tuesday.
I'd like to thank you all for coming and for a very productive meeting.

senses.definition: if you say that something is a foregone conclusion, you mean that it is a result that is certain to happen
examples: The outcome of the vote is a foregone conclusion.
The result of the game was a foregone conclusion.

senses.definition: to make a decision about somebody/something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts
examples: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.
Don't jump to conclusions.
We don't want to jump to the wrong conclusion.

senses.definition: the state that something is in
examples: in… condition to be in pristine/excellent/perfect condition
Many of the paintings are in poor condition.
the condition of something The condition of the roads is poor.
the present state of medical knowledge
We’re worried about his mental state.
What a state this room is in (= very bad).
The car is in excellent condition
The car is still in excellent condition.
The clock was restored to its original condition.
I didn't like to think about the condition of my finances.
The car was in perfect condition.
The furniture was not in a particularly good condition.
The poor condition of our schools should be of concern to all of us.
What kind of condition is the washing machine in?

senses.definition: the state of somebody’s health or how fit they are
examples: He is overweight and out of condition (= not physically fit).
in (a)… condition The motorcyclist was in a critical condition (= at risk of dying) in hospital last night.
in a stable/serious condition
You are in no condition (= too ill/sick, etc.) to go anywhere.
(informal) in somebody's condition She shouldn't be smoking in her condition (= because she is pregnant).
Her condition has deteriorated.
You're in no condition to tackle the stairs.
a young athlete in peak condition
Without this treatment, her condition won't improve.
Doctors say his condition is now stable.
I haven't been exercising much recently, so I'm a bit out of condition.
In his weakened condition, it took a long time for the wound to heal.
There has been a marked deterioration in her mental condition.
Her condition is said to be stable.
He is still in (a) critical condition in the hospital.

senses.definition: an illness or a medical problem that you have for a long time because it is not possible to cure it
examples: Does your child have any kind of medical condition that we should know about?
She has a serious health condition.
a heart/skin condition
He suffers from a serious heart condition.
The drug is used to treat conditions such as epilepsy.
He suffers from a rare blood disease.
She died after a long illness.
a rare disorder of the liver
a throat infection
a heart condition
childhood ailments
a stomach bug
All three babies were born with an incurable heart condition.
Psychoanalysts attribute this tendency to a pathological condition.
He has a rare skin condition.
She was unable to give informed consent because of a mental condition.
The insurance will not cover you for a pre-existing condition.

senses.definition: the circumstances or situation in which people live, work or do things
examples: working/living conditions
economic/market conditions
under… conditions They were working under appalling conditions.
a strike over pay and conditions
conditions for somebody to improve conditions for workers
(in) conditions of something He grew up in conditions of poverty.
the present economic situation
The ship sank in mysterious circumstances.
She felt she was in a position of power.
We were forced to work outside in freezing conditions.
Hi, Jane! How are things?
Think things over before you decide.
If that is the case (= if the situation described is true), we need more staff.
How did this unhappy state of affairs come about?
An enormous number of people live in conditions of poverty.
The working conditions in the factory are dreadful.
an effort to improve working conditions at the plant
people working under stressful conditions
Conditions are ideal for starting a business.

senses.definition: the physical situation that affects how something happens
examples: in … conditions The plants grow best in cool, damp conditions.
The boat sank in adverse weather conditions.
dry/wet/harsh conditions
under… conditions Studies show that the drug may be harmful under certain conditions.
extreme environmental conditions
treacherous driving conditions
Conditions are ideal for sailing today.
Animals adapt to changing environmental conditions.
As long as these weather conditions prevail, we are unable to rescue the climbers.
Paint shades can vary under different lighting conditions.
The chamber simulates conditions found at high altitudes.
The experiment is conducted under strictly controlled conditions.
The samples are heated under experimental conditions.
Warm, wet weather can create ideal conditions for plant diseases.
adverse conditions for driving
freak weather conditions
in normal flight operating conditions
plants that can survive dry conditions

senses.definition: a rule or decision that you must agree to, sometimes forming part of a contract or an official agreement
examples: The offer is subject to certain conditions.
on (the) condition that… They agreed to lend us the car on condition that (= only if) we returned it before the weekend.
on condition of something The officials spoke on condition of anonymity.
They will give us the money on one condition—that we pay it back within six months.
under the condition that… (especially North American English) They agreed under the condition that the matter be dealt with promptly.
Congress can impose strict conditions on the bank.
to satisfy/meet/fulfill a condition
They have agreed to a ceasefire provided their conditions are met.
He denied being in breach of bail conditions.
I'll agree to the plan on one condition: my name doesn't get mentioned to the press.
Special conditions apply to the use of the library's rare books.
The UN has imposed strict conditions on the ceasefire.

They would not agree to our conditions.
To get a basic pension you must satisfy two conditions.
Under the conditions of the agreement, all foreign troops will leave by May.
the conditions attached to the grant of a residential licence
the terms and conditions of the contract

senses.definition: a situation that must exist in order for something else to happen
examples: condition for something Stable political leadership is a necessary condition for economic growth.
conditions for investment/success/development
We are working to create the conditions for peace.
as a condition of something Applicants must agree to teach for three years as a condition of admission to the program.
as a condition of doing something You can't make a consumer buy something as a condition of getting a loan.
Letting go of the past is one of the conditions for a lasting peace.
a necessary and sufficient condition for the eradication of unemployment

senses.definition: the state of a particular group of people because of their situation in life, their problems, etc.
examples: He spoke angrily about the condition of the urban poor.
Work is basic to the human condition (= the fact of being alive).
We are aiming to improve the condition of the urban poor.

senses.definition: new or as good as new; in perfect condition
examples: We sell first editions of rare books in mint condition.

senses.definition: not in any situation; never
examples: You must on no condition tell them what happened.

senses.definition: a person’s behaviour in a particular place or in a particular situation
examples: The sport has a strict code of conduct.
improving standards of training and professional conduct
Any allegation of criminal conduct has to be taken seriously.
a complaint about the conduct of a police officer
conduct towards somebody The United player was fined £5 000 for improper conduct towards an official.
He was arrested for disorderly conduct.
a charge of engaging in conduct likely to cause death or serious injury
It is tempting to think of morality as a guide to human conduct.
Our organization sets high standards of professional conduct.
The committee concluded that the senators had engaged in improper conduct.
The minister was called to court to explain his conduct.
The police chief was asked to explain his conduct.
The prisoner was released early for good conduct.
The violent conduct by the strikers was condemned.
conduct constituting a crime
her conduct towards her husband
rules governing police conduct
a study of conduct problems in children

senses.definition: the way in which a business or an activity is organized and managed
examples: There was growing criticism of the government's conduct of the war.
The release of this information could compromise the proper conduct of the investigation.
Most directors are not involved in the day-to-day conduct of the business.
The elders were responsible for the proper conduct of community life.

senses.definition: to organize and/or do a particular activity
examples: to conduct an experiment/inquiry/investigation/interview
to conduct a survey/poll/study/review
to conduct a test/trial
to conduct research/business
There are concerns about the way in which the firm conducts its activities.
The battalion had been preparing to conduct operations in the same area.
Police conducted a thorough search of the building.
The negotiations have been conducted in a positive manner.
They conducted a vigorous campaign for a shorter working week.
They conduct workshops on topics such as women's legal rights.

Today, most opinion polls are conducted online.
We regularly conduct safety inspections.

People have criticized the way she conducted her election campaign.
The interrogation was conducted by senior police officers.
The search for the missing men was conducted in poor weather conditions.
We conducted the experiment under controlled conditions.

senses.definition: to direct a group of people who are singing or playing music
examples: a concert by the London Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Marin Alsop
He conducted a programme of Sibelius and Tchaikovsky.
He will conduct works by Brahms and Schumann in tonight's concert.

senses.definition: to lead or guide somebody through or around a place
examples: a conducted tour of Athens (= one with a guide, giving information about it)

A guide conducted us around the museum.
How about a personally conducted tour of the house?

The guide conducted them around the ancient ruins.

senses.definition: to behave in a particular way
examples: He conducted himself far better than expected.

He always conducted himself as a gentleman.

senses.definition: to allow heat or electricity to pass along or through it
examples: Copper conducts electricity well.

Copper conducts electricity better than other materials do.
Superconductors are materials that can conduct electricity without resistance at low temperatures.

senses.definition: a large official meeting, usually lasting for a few days, at which people with the same work or interests come together to discuss their views
examples: The hotel is used for exhibitions, conferences and social events.

to speak at/address a conference

the national conference of the American Psychiatric Association
at a conference We met at an international conference.

conference on something She is attending a three-day conference on climate change.
conference for somebody a conference for health professionals from around the world

a conference devoted to the topic of peace
a conference entitled ‘Strategies for Epidemic Control’
a conference examining cross-border cooperation
a conference for catering managers
a conference on economic aid
an intergovernmental conference examining cross-border cooperation

senses.definition: a meeting at which people have formal discussions
examples: They agreed to convene a peace conference by mid-November.
conference with somebody Her working day consists of conferences with foreign diplomats.
in conference (with somebody) He was in conference with his lawyers all day.
Ministers from all four countries involved will meet at the conference table this week.
Management had a joint conference with the union.
a conference between the warring parties

senses.definition: a group of sports teams that play against each other in a league
examples: Southeast Conference football champions

senses.definition: the feeling that you can trust, believe in and be sure about the abilities or good qualities of somebody/something
examples: The president's actions hardly inspire confidence.

He expressed confidence in the new plans.

The government lost a confidence vote.
They are gradually instilling confidence in their staff.

a loss of confidence among investors
an effort to renew investor confidence in corporate America
an environment which builds mutual confidence

public confidence in the government
to maintain public confidence in the system of justice

senses.definition: a belief in your own ability to do things and be successful
examples: People often lose confidence when they are criticized.

with confidence She answered the questions with confidence.
confidence in something/yourself I didn't have any confidence in myself at school.

confidence to do something The training programmes have given workers the confidence to take on more responsibility.
Their confidence grew with each success.

As the weeks went by he grew in confidence.

The training is designed to give staff confidence in managing problems.

Getting the certificate does a lot in terms of confidence building.
She's really striking the ball well and has got her confidence back.

He's gained a lot of confidence over the last year.
Since she got the new job, she's been brimming with confidence.

Winning the competition really boosted her confidence.
a man who exudes confidence
his confidence in himself

senses.definition: the feeling that you are certain about something
examples: He said he wished that he shared her confidence.
with confidence They could not say with confidence that he would be able to walk again after the accident.
No one can predict with complete confidence what will happen in the financial markets.
confidence that… She expressed her confidence that they would win.

senses.definition: a feeling of trust that somebody will keep information private
examples: It took a long time to gain her confidence (= make her feel she could trust me).

I really can't talk about this—she told me in confidence.

She told me in confidence—I couldn't break that confidence, could I?
Telling other people what I'd said was a total breach of confidence.

senses.definition: a secret that you tell somebody
examples: The girls exchanged confidences.
I could never forgive Mike for betraying a confidence.
She didn't encourage confidences.
The boys exchanged whispered confidences.
Can you keep a confidence?

senses.definition: to be trusted with somebody’s secrets
examples: He is said to be very much in the president's confidence.

senses.definition: to tell somebody secrets and personal information about yourself
examples: She took me into her confidence and told me about the problems she was facing.

senses.definition: feeling sure about your own ability to do things and be successful
examples: She was in a relaxed, confident mood.
Beneath his confident and charming exterior lurked a mass of insecurities.
confident about something I was actually fairly confident about my chances.
confident about doing something The teacher wants the children to feel confident about asking questions when they don't understand.
confident in something He'd learned to be confident in his ability to handle anything life threw at him.
Going to university has made her more confident.

He's becoming more confident as he gets older.
She gradually grew more confident.
She sauntered onto the set, looking serenely confident.

senses.definition: feeling certain that something will happen in the way that you want or expect
examples: confident of something The Democrats were confident of victory.
confident of doing something The team feels confident of winning.
confident about something We are confident about the future.
confident (that)… I'm confident that you will get the job.

We're pretty confident we can win the case.

‘Is that John over there?’ ‘I’m not sure.’

‘Are you sure?’ ‘Positive.’

I'm quite confident that you'll get the job.

senses.definition: to state or show that something is definitely true or correct, especially by providing evidence
examples: confirm something His guilty expression confirmed my suspicions.
to confirm a diagnosis/report
to confirm results/findings

confirm (that)… Police sources confirmed that ten people had been arrested at the march.
confirm to somebody/something that… A government official confirmed to the newspaper that Britain was pushing hard for an end to the arms embargo.
confirm what/when, etc… Can you confirm what happened?
it is confirmed that… It has been confirmed that an official complaint was made to the council.

senses.definition: to make a position, an agreement, etc. more definite or official; to establish somebody/something clearly
examples: confirm something Please write to confirm your reservation (= say that it is definite).
After a six-month probationary period, her position was confirmed.
confirm (that)… Has everyone confirmed (that) they’re coming?
it is confirmed that… It has been confirmed that the meeting will take place next week.
confirm somebody as something He was confirmed as captain for the rest of the season.
confirm somebody in something I'm very happy to confirm you in your post.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel or believe something even more strongly

senses.definition: to perform the Christian or Jewish ceremony of confirmation
examples: be confirmed She was baptized when she was a month old and confirmed when she was thirteen.

senses.definition: a situation in which people, groups or countries disagree strongly or are involved in a serious argument
examples: The violence was the result of political conflicts.
conflict between A and B (over something) a conflict between two cultures

conflict with somebody The prime minister wants to avoid conflict with the unions.
conflict over something The government has done nothing to resolve the conflict over nurses' pay.
in conflict with somebody (over something) She found herself in conflict with her parents over her future career.

conflict within something The terms of the will became a source of conflict within the family.

a conflict over ownership of the land
conflicts between different ethnic groups
in conflict with management
serious conflicts within the ruling party
the key to successful conflict management

senses.definition: a violent situation or period of fighting between two countries
examples: armed/military conflict

Hopes of ending the conflict in the region are fading.
international efforts to find a peaceful solution to the conflict
conflict with somebody This isolated state faces the risk of another violent conflict with its neighbour.
conflict over something They are engaged in a bloody conflict over the disputed territory.
conflict between A and B (over something) A conflict between the two countries could easily spread across the whole region.

to end the conflict with its northern neighbour

senses.definition: a situation in which there are ideas, opinions, feelings or wishes that are opposed to each other; a situation in which it is difficult to choose
examples: Her diary was a record of her inner conflict.
conflict between A and B The story tells of a classic conflict between love and duty.
in conflict with something Many of these ideas appear to be in conflict with each other.
conflict of something He faced a conflict of loyalties.
a serious conflict of opinion
in direct conflict with his wishes
the conflict between science and religion
the inherent conflict between what farmers and environmentalists want
the inherent conflict between the demands of farmers and wishes of environmentalists

senses.definition: a situation in which somebody has two jobs, aims, roles, etc. and cannot treat both of them equally and fairly at the same time

senses.definition: if two ideas, beliefs, stories, etc. conflict, it is not possible for them to exist together or for them both to be true
examples: Reports conflicted on how much of the aid was reaching the famine victims.

senses.definition: to make somebody unable to think clearly or understand something

senses.definition: to think wrongly that somebody/something is somebody/something else

senses.definition: to make a subject more difficult to understand

senses.definition: unable to think clearly or to understand what is happening or what somebody is saying

confused by something She seemed confused by the question.

I'm confused by the whole thing.

senses.definition: not clear or easy to understand
examples: The children gave a confused account of what had happened.

senses.definition: difficult to understand; not clear

a confusing situation/experience
confusing messages/signals

speedy internet connections

senses.definition: a point, especially in an electrical system, where two parts connect

senses.definition: a game in which each player writes the first line of a story on a piece of paper and then passes it to the next player who writes the second line, and so on. We are the biggest consumers of tropical hardwoods after Japan.
We supply domestic consumers

two years of research among consumers

senses.definition: the act of communicating with somebody, especially regularly
examples: contact with somebody I don't have much contact with my uncle.

senses.definition: the state of meeting somebody or having to deal with something

senses.definition: an electrical connection
examples: The switches close the contacts and complete the circuit.

senses.definition: a contact lens (= a small round piece of thin plastic that you put on your eye to help you see better)
a person who has recently been near to somebody with a contagious disease and so might have caught the infection from them
a place where you go or a person that you speak to when you are dealing with an organization

senses.definition: to communicate with somebody, for example by phone, letter or email
examples: I've been trying to contact you all day.

senses.definition: if something contains something else, it has that thing inside it or as part of it

senses.definition: a box, bottle, etc. in which something can be stored or transported

senses.definition: belonging to the same time
examples: We have no contemporary account of the battle (= written near the time that it happened).

senses.definition: belonging to the present time

senses.definition: following modern ideas in style or design
examples: Try some contemporary colours on your kitchen walls.

senses.definition: the things that are contained in something
examples: He tipped the contents of the bag onto the table.

examples: a table of contents (= the list at the front of a book)

senses.definition: the subject matter of a book, speech, programme, etc.
examples: Her poetry has a good deal of political content.

senses.definition: the amount of a substance that is contained in something else

senses.definition: the information or other material contained on a website or other digital media

delivering premium content to users
a method of sharing content over the internet

senses.definition: a competition in which people try to win something
examples: to hold a singing/talent contest
to enter/win a contest
in a contest She was awarded the first prize in an essay contest .
contest between A and B It was a close contest between two evenly matched crews.
contest with somebody He said he had enjoyed the contest with his rival for the title .

senses.definition: a struggle to gain control or power
examples: the leadership/presidential contest

contest for something a contest for the leadership of the party
contest between A and B a contest between traditional and liberal views

senses.definition: used to say that one side in a competition is so much stronger or better than the other that it is sure to win easily

examples: Three candidates contested the leadership.

senses.definition: to formally oppose a decision or statement because you think it is wrong

senses.definition: the situation in which something happens and that helps you to understand it
examples: to examine the wider/broader context of the war

senses.definition: to keep existing or happening without stopping

senses.definition: happening or existing for a period of time without being interrupted

senses.definition: connected with the form of a verb (for example I am waiting or It is raining) that is made from a part of be and the present participle. Progressive forms are used to express an action that continues for a period of time.

senses.definition: an official written agreement
examples: All employees have a written contract of employment.
a research/modelling/recording contract

to renew/extend/terminate/cancel a contract
on a contract I was on a three-year contract that expired last week.

out of contract The phone costs several hundred dollars more out of contract (= without a contract with a phone company).

subject to contract The offer has been accepted, subject to contract (= the agreement is not official until the contract is signed).

the company fulfilling the construction contract
the contract between the employer and the employee

senses.definition: an agreement to kill somebody for money

senses.definition: to become less or smaller; to make something become less or smaller

contract something to something ‘I will’ and ‘I shall’ are usually contracted to ‘I'll’ (= made shorter).
The electrical market is forecast to contract by 2% this year.

senses.definition: to get an illness
examples: to contract a virus/a disease/measles

senses.definition: to make a legal agreement with somebody for them to work for you or provide you with a service
examples: contract somebody to do something The player is contracted to play until August.

senses.definition: to make a legal agreement to work for somebody or provide them with a service
examples: She has contracted to work 20 hours a week.

senses.definition: to formally agree to marry somebody/form an alliance with somebody

a difference between two or more people or things that you can see clearly when they are compared or put close together; the fact of comparing two or more things in order to show the differences between them
examples: The two cities make an interesting contrast.
contrast between A and B There is an obvious contrast between the cultures of East and West.
in contrast In contrast, the south suffered very little hurricane damage.
in contrast to somebody/something The situation when we arrived was in marked contrast to the news reports.
The poverty of her childhood stands in total contrast to her life in Hollywood.
The company lost $7 million this quarter in contrast to a profit of $6.2 million a year earlier.
contrast with somebody/something to show a sharp/stark/striking contrast with something
contrast in something A wool jacket complements the silk trousers and provides an interesting contrast in texture.
by contrast When you look at their new system, ours seems very old-fashioned by contrast.
contrast of A and B Careful contrast of the two plans shows some important differences.
This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the UK spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the phone or on social networking websites.
Compared to the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the phone.
On average the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.
The company lost $13 million this year, in contrast to a profit of $15 million last year.
The contrast between the sisters was very strong.
The contrast in appearance between the sisters was striking.
The flowers provide a contrast with the dark background.
The fresh fruit provides a contrast with the rich chocolate pudding.
The writer emphasizes the contrast between conventional and alternative medicine.
When you look at their new system, ours seems very old-fashioned by contrast.
Their attitudes to marriage stand in stark contrast to those of their parents.
There is a stark contrast between the lives of the rich and those of the poor.
There is a striking contrast between the two painters' work.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is clearly different from somebody/something else
examples: The work you did today is quite a contrast to (= very much better/worse than) what you did last week.
This busy social life was a complete contrast to his old quiet life.
Her hair was black, a stunning contrast to her pale complexion.

senses.definition: differences in colour or in light and dark, used in photographs and paintings to create a special effect
examples: The artist's use of contrast is masterly.

senses.definition: the amount of difference between light and dark in a photograph or the picture on a television screen
examples: Use this button to adjust the contrast.

senses.definition: to compare two things in order to show the differences between them
examples: contrast A and B The poem contrasts youth and age.
Compare and contrast the two novels (= discuss how they are similar and how they are different).
contrast A with B It is interesting to contrast the British legal system with the American one.

senses.definition: to show a clear difference when close together or when compared
examples: A contrasts with B Her actions contrasted sharply with her promises.
A and B contrast Her actions and her promises contrasted sharply.
This statement contrasts starkly with his previous statements.
The open approach contrasts favourably with the exclusivity of some universities.
His cream shirt contrasted beautifully with his tan skin.

senses.definition: to give something, especially money or goods, to help achieve or provide something
examples: Do you wish to contribute?
contribute to/towards something Would you like to contribute to our collection?
to contribute to your pension
contribute something Check with your financial planner to make sure that you are contributing the correct amounts.
contribute something to/towards something We contributed £5 000 to the earthquake fund.
I would like to contribute to the church restoration fund.

The company contributed $50 000 towards training costs.
a situation where husband and wife contribute equally to the family budget

senses.definition: to be one of the causes of something
examples: Human error may have been a contributing factor.
contribute to something It is well known that UV radiation contributes to the development of skin cancer.

Medical negligence was said to have contributed to her death.

US policy has contributed to the problem.

Changes in lifestyle and diet over the last twenty years have caused/led to/resulted in a sharp increase in childhood obesity.
Several factors, including changes in diet and lifestyle, have contributed to the increase in childhood obesity.
Research suggests that fast food and soft drinks directly contribute to childhood obesity.
Genetics, lifestyle and diet are all important factors in cases of childhood obesity.
Even small changes in lifestyle and diet can bring about significant weight loss.
Several factors might contribute to the development of the disease.
These images could potentially contribute to the development of eating disorders.
Unemployment contributes directly to homelessness.
countries that contribute disproportionately to global warming

senses.definition: to increase, improve or add to something
examples: contribute to something Immigrants have contributed to British culture in many ways.
Parental involvement contributes significantly to children's learning.
Hall's work contributed greatly to our knowledge of the disease.
contribute something to something This book contributes little to our understanding of the subject.
His research has contributed enormously to our understanding of this disease.
people who want to contribute positively to their communities

senses.definition: to write things for a newspaper, book, website, etc. or a radio or television programme; to speak during a meeting or conversation, especially to give your opinion
examples: The blog now has about 20 people contributing regularly.
a contributing editor
contribute to something We hope everyone will contribute to the discussion.
Associated Press contributed to this report.
contribute something He contributed a piece on Canadian law.
contribute something to something She contributed a number of articles to the magazine.
He contributes regularly to the magazine ‘New Scientist’.

a talented photographer who contributed to many books on architectiure

senses.definition: a gift or payment that is made to a person or an organization in order to help pay for something
examples: All contributions will be gratefully received.
We rely entirely on voluntary contributions.
campaign contributions
contribution to something to make a substantial contribution to charity
contribution towards something valuable contributions towards the upkeep of the cathedral
contribution towards doing something She argued that a greater contribution towards reducing Britain's record debts should be asked of the better off.
contribution from/by somebody/something Financial contributions from individuals paid for office and printing expenses.
I'd like to make a small contribution to the cost of the holiday.
We were asked to make a contribution towards the cost of the meal.

senses.definition: a sum of money that you pay regularly to your employer or the government in order to pay for benefits such as health insurance, a pension, etc.
examples: pension contributions
National Insurance contributions
contribution to something You can increase your monthly contributions to the pension plan.
contribution from/by somebody Pension funds base retirement income on the level of contributions from employees and employers.
ten monthly payments of $50
payment in advance
an insurance premium
a premium for express delivery
You can increase your monthly contributions to the pension plan.
a subscription to Netflix
the repayments on the loan
We've put down a 5 per cent deposit on the house.
We paid for the car by/​in instalments.
employers' pension and health insurance contributions
