senses.definition: to cheat in an exam, school work, etc. by writing what somebody else has written and pretending it is your own work
examples: He was punished by his teacher for copying in the exam.
copy from/off somebody She was caught copying off another student.
copy something Copying other students' work is not acceptable.

senses.definition: to make a photocopy of something
examples: Finally, the notes can be copied and distributed to the audience.

senses.definition: most important; main or essential
examples: core subjects (= subjects that all the students have to study) such as English and mathematics
the core curriculum
We need to concentrate on our core business.
The government's proposed solution fails to address the core issue.
core to something The use of new technology is core to our strategy.
the core area of management studies
What are the core activities of the job?
Maths, English and science are the core subjects.
We need to stop this expansion and concentrate on the core business.
Students study five core subjects.

senses.definition: used to describe the most important or central beliefs, etc. of a person or group
examples: core beliefs/principles
The party is losing touch with its core values.

senses.definition: used to describe the most important members of a group
examples: The team is built around a core group of players.

senses.definition: the most important or central part of something
examples: This report goes to the core of the argument.
Dutch paintings form the core of the collection.
at the core of something Concern for the environment is at the core of our policies.
Our need for love lies at the very core of our being.
She claimed the original six countries of the EU constituted an inner core within the larger union.
None of the characters really gives the film an emotional core.
A new spirit welled up from the very core of the nation.
At the core of our convictions is belief in individual liberty.
There was a hollow core of sadness inside me.
These ideas formed the core of his philosophy.
This is seen as the central core of the government's policy.
We want to get to the core of the problem.
a common core of shared understanding about law and government
the emotional core of her music
This was a man he detested from the core of his heart.

senses.definition: the central part of an object
examples: the earth’s core
the core of a nuclear reactor
The standards of housing and education are often lower in the older urban cores (= the centres of towns or cities).
heat from the earth's core
Each fibre has a hollow core trapping still air and aiding warmth.

senses.definition: the hard central part of a fruit such as an apple, that contains the seeds
examples: an apple core

senses.definition: the muscles of the lower back and stomach area which help you to maintain good balance, etc.
examples: Your posture will improve as your core becomes stronger.

senses.definition: a small group of people who take part in a particular activity
examples: He gathered a small core of advisers around him.

senses.definition: so that the whole of a thing or a person is affected
examples: She was shaken to the core by the news.
He's a politician to the core (= in all his attitudes and actions).

senses.definition: a part of something where two or more sides, lines or edges join
examples: the four corners of a square
I hit my knee on the corner of the table.
Write your address in the top right-hand corner of the letter.
the left/right corner
the north-west/north-east/south-east/south-west corner
A smile lifted the corner of his mouth.
in the corner of something a speck of dirt in the corner of her eye
He scored with a shot into the bottom corner of the goal.
She tucked the ball into the corner of the net.
He parked in the far corner of the car park.
Smooth rounded corners make cleaning easier.
the four corners of his bed

senses.definition: with the number of corners mentioned; involving the number of groups mentioned
examples: a three-cornered hat
a three-cornered fight

senses.definition: the place inside a room or a box where two sides join; the area around this place
examples: A large desk occupies another corner of the room.
He found a quiet corner and got on with his work.
in the corner They made straight for the table in the corner.
in the corner of something She spotted him sitting in the corner of the cafe.
We found an empty booth in a dark corner of the restaurant.
There was a television in the far corner of the bedroom.
a corner table/seat/cupboard
He took a seat in the far corner of the cafe.
Make sure the staircase is well lit, with no awkward corners.
She sat in a dark corner of the room.
She tucked herself away in a corner and read all day.
The box had been tucked away in an odd corner of the attic.
The waiter led us to a corner table.
They chose a table right in the corner of the restaurant.

senses.definition: a place where two streets join
examples: The wind hit him as he turned the corner.
corner of A and B the last house before the corner of Beach Road and Hill Avenue
on the corner There was a group of youths standing on the street corner.
on the corner of something There’s a hotel on the corner of my street.
at the corner (of something) Turn right at the corner of Sunset and Crescent Heights Boulevards.
around/round the corner The bus stop is around the corner, I think.
around/round the corner from something the bookshop around the corner from our hotel
(at the) corner with something the big tree at the corner with Hill Street
the bank on the corner of Mount Street
at the corner of West Street and Park Street
Turn right at the first corner.
There were a lot of young men hanging about on street corners.

senses.definition: a sharp bend in a road
examples: The car was taking the corners too fast.
I hate coming out of that lane because it's a blind corner.
It's a rather sharp corner and she took it a little too fast.
As they turned the corner all the bags slid to one side.

senses.definition: a region or an area of a place (sometimes used for one that is far away or difficult to reach)
examples: She lives in a quiet corner of rural Yorkshire.
Students come here from the four corners of the world.
He knew every corner of the old town.
Welcome to our little corner of Philadelphia.
a cool shady corner of the garden
a remote corner of Afghanistan
He pushed the thought back into the darkest corner of his mind.

senses.definition: a difficult situation
examples: to back/drive/force somebody into a corner
They had got her in a corner, and there wasn't much she could do about it.
He was used to talking his way out of tight corners.
It is important to avoid being pushed into a corner.
He had her backed into a corner a couple of times with new facts she didn't know.
I'm in a bit of a corner over finding staff for Friday evening.
He was used to having to talk his way out of tight corners.

senses.definition: a free kick or hit that you take from the corner of your opponent’s end of the field
examples: Moore took the corner.
The referee awarded a corner.
Sancho took the corner and Kane headed it into the net.
She put the goalkeeper under pressure and managed to force a corner.
James blocked the shot but conceded a corner.

senses.definition: any of the four corners of a ring; the supporters who help in the corner
very near
examples: Her house is just around the corner.
(figurative) There were good times around the corner (= they would soon come).

senses.definition: to support and encourage somebody; to have somebody who supports and encourages you
examples: He's been in my corner all these years and I can never thank him enough.

senses.definition: to go across the corner of an area and not around the sides of it, because it is quicker
examples: There’s a worn patch on the grass because everyone cuts (off) the corner.

senses.definition: to do something in the easiest, cheapest or quickest way, often by ignoring rules or leaving something out
examples: To be competitive, they paid low wages and cut corners on health and safety.

senses.definition: to defend your/somebody’s position against other people
to like somebody/something
examples: She's always had a soft corner for you.

senses.definition: in a difficult situation
examples: The captain's knee injury leaves the team in a tight corner.
She’ll always help if you’re in a tight spot.
This could put the banks in a corner.

senses.definition: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it
examples: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

senses.definition: to pass a very important point in an illness or a difficult situation and begin to improve
examples: The country's economy has finally turned the corner.

senses.definition: connected with a large business company
examples: corporate finance/profits/tax
corporate executives/clients/sponsors
corporate identity (= the image of a company, which all its members share)
corporate hospitality (= when companies entertain customers to help develop good business relationships)
initiatives to improve standards of corporate governance
the prevailing mood in the boardrooms of corporate America
Their corporate headquarters are in Boston.

senses.definition: forming a corporation (= an organization or group of organizations that is recognized by law as a single unit)
examples: The BBC is a corporate organization.
The law applies both to individuals and to corporate bodies.

senses.definition: involving or shared by all the members of a group
examples: a corporate act of worship in the College chapel

senses.definition: accurate or true, without any mistakes
examples: Do you have the correct time?
the correct answer
When asked to pick the correct meaning from four alternatives, students consistently chose the correct one.
Please check that these details are correct.
‘Are you in charge here?’ ‘That's correct.’
As always, your grandmother is absolutely correct.
correct in something They were correct in their assessment of the situation.
correct in doing something Am I correct in saying that you know a lot about art?
it is correct to do something It is correct to say that Camus's philosophy can be divided into two periods.
it is correct (that)… It is correct that there are some similarities between the two cases.
Are the following statements true or false?
Is it true (that) she’s leaving?
I got about half the answers right.
What’s the right time?
Only one of the answers is correct.
Check that all the details are correct.
His estimate has turned out to be more or less correct.
Her first idea proved correct.
I think I am correct in saying that this project is the first of its kind in this country.
None of the explanations offered is demonstrably correct—or demonstrably incorrect.
The diagram is correct in every detail.
The flower drawings are all to scale and botanically correct.
The sentence is grammatically correct, but not very idiomatic.
What you say is perfectly correct, but it gives the wrong impression.
Check that all the details are correct.
I don't think she's correct to say he's incompetent.
Only one of the answers is correct.
They say that he was against women getting the vote, but that's not entirely correct.

senses.definition: right and suitable, so that something is done as it should be done
examples: the correct procedure/approach
Do you know the correct way to shut the machine down?
I think you've made the correct decision.
You’re right to be cautious.
You made the right decision.
‘It’s not easy.’ ‘Yes, you’re right.’
What’s the correct way to shut the machine down?
I don’t think she’s correct to say he’s incompetent.

senses.definition: taking care to speak or behave in a way that follows the accepted standards or rules
examples: a correct young woman
He is always very correct in his speech.

senses.definition: used to say that all the things or people who should be there are now there
to make something right or accurate, for example by changing it or removing mistakes
examples: correct something to correct an error
Read through your work and correct any mistakes that you find.
I thought we had corrected the problem.
Their eyesight can be corrected in just a few minutes by the use of a laser.
They issued a statement correcting the one they had made earlier.
correct yourself He stopped and corrected himself. ‘I mean fifteen, not fifty.’
correct something for something The data were corrected for differences in age.
At this stage you should be able to correct at least some of your own mistakes.
I'd like to correct the impression that my client has any kind of criminal record.
Minor problems with eyesight can now be corrected in a few seconds.
They issued a statement correcting what they had said earlier.

senses.definition: to mark the mistakes in a piece of work (and sometimes give a mark to the work)
examples: I spent all evening correcting essays.
It's simply not true that teachers no longer correct bad spellings.
When I've corrected your assignments, I want you to write them out again.

senses.definition: to tell somebody that they have made a mistake
examples: correct somebody Correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't this last year's brochure?
Yes, you're right—I stand corrected (= I accept that I made a mistake).
correct somebody + speech ‘It's Yates, not Wates,’ she corrected him.
‘She's his girlfriend.’ ‘His sister,’ Ian corrected.
I'll be there at five fifteen, I mean five fifty—ten to six.
It'll be Tuesday—sorry, I meant to say Thursday.
Sorry, what I mean is, we need two handouts per person.
We can meet in the conference centre—or rather in front of the centre.
The painter—or should I say, the sculptor—was born in Padua.
It's one t and double s—no, sorry, one s and double t.
It's on the fifth floor—no, actually, it's the fourth.
Can I get two lattes and an espresso—no, scratch that—three lattes?
There are three items on tonight's agenda. Correction, four items.

senses.definition: in a way that is accurate or true, without any mistakes
examples: Have you spelled it correctly?
Students correctly identified 16 trees species found on their study sites.
If I remember correctly, he was still the prime minister at that point.
They reasoned, correctly, that she was away for the weekend.

senses.definition: in a way that is right and suitable, so that something is done as it should be done
examples: When correctly applied, fake tan is difficult to tell from the real thing.

senses.definition: in a way that follows the accepted standards or rules
examples: He was looking correctly grave.

senses.definition: the amount of money that you need in order to buy, make or do something
examples: cost of something the high/low cost of housing
at a cost of something A new computer system has been installed at a cost of £80 000.

cost to somebody The total cost to you (= the amount you have to pay) is £3 000.
cost for somebody/something Energy is a major cost for businesses.
She estimates the cost for this project at $150 000.
house prices
How much are these? They don’t have a price on them.
I can’t afford it at that price.
A new computer system has been installed at a cost of £80 000.
The winner will receive a prize to the value of £1 000.
The garden was transformed at great expense.
Running a car is a big expense.
He has a personal net worth of $10 million.
A total of 3.6 million tickets at an average cost of $58 are available for the Games.

Competition will drive the price down near to the marginal cost.

Delegates receive allowances to meet the cost of travel.

The corporation will pay all costs and expenses incurred with its written consent.

The cost to the government will be quite high.
The entire project carries a cost of $2 million.
The high cost of energy was a problem for consumers.
The hotel offers tea and coffee at no extra cost.
There were cost overruns on each project.
We're hoping that we'll at least cover costs at the conference.
What is the current replacement cost of these assets?
You can spread the cost of your loan repayment over 10 years.
You will have to bear the full cost of the building work.
the cost per day for an electrician
the pursuit of cost reduction
The true cost of running a car is much greater than just the price of the petrol you use.

senses.definition: the total amount of money that needs to be spent by a business
examples: The use of cheap labour helped to keep costs down.
Reducing costs means we can keep prices as low as possible.
We have to find new ways of cutting costs.
The company is focused on lowering its operating costs.
We have had to raise our prices because of rising costs.
Opinion was divided on the potential costs and benefits of the scheme.
labour/​production costs
rising costs
public spending
More spending on health was promised.
expenditure on education
legal expenses
travel expenses

The best equipment is costly but is well worth the outlay.
The company's costs have risen over the last 5 years.
the costs associated with buying and selling property
The capital cost of these projects is some $100 million—then there'll be the operating costs.
research and development costs

senses.definition: the effort, loss or damage that is involved in order to do or achieve something
examples: the cost of something the terrible cost of the war in death and suffering
the environmental cost of nuclear power
at the cost of something She saved him from the fire at the cost of her own life (= she died).
at… cost Victory came at a high cost.
at… cost in something They advanced a few hundred metres, but at a heavy cost in life.
at (a) cost to something He worked non-stop for three months, at considerable cost to his health.
cost in something I felt a need to please people, whatever the cost in time and energy.

The raid was foiled, but at a cost: an injured officer who was lucky to survive.
The country has suffered the enormous cost of trade sanctions.
Do the benefits outweigh the costs?
the costs and benefits of this strategy

senses.definition: the sum of money that somebody is ordered to pay for lawyers, etc. in a legal case
examples: He was ordered to pay £2 000 costs.

If you win your case you will normally be awarded costs.

senses.definition: whatever is needed to achieve something
examples: You must stop the press from finding out at all costs.

senses.definition: under any circumstances
examples: He is determined to win at any cost.

senses.definition: for only the amount of money that is needed to make or get something, without any profit being added on
examples: goods sold at cost

senses.definition: to feel the bad effects of a mistake, an accident, etc.
examples: The town is now counting the cost of its failure to provide adequate flood protection.

senses.definition: to know something because of something unpleasant that has happened to you
examples: She is a tough competitor, as I know to my cost.

senses.definition: if something costs a particular amount of money, you need to pay that amount in order to buy, make or do it
examples: cost something How much did it cost?
I didn't get it because it cost too much.
Tickets cost ten dollars each.
Calls to the helpline cost 45p per minute.
Don't use too much of it—it cost a lot of money.
All these reforms will cost money (= be expensive).
Good food need not cost a fortune (= cost a lot of money).
cost somebody something The meal cost us about £40.
This is costing the taxpayer £10 billion a year.
cost something to do something The hospital will cost an estimated £2 billion to build.
It costs a fortune to fly first class.

senses.definition: to cause the loss of something
examples: cost somebody something That one mistake almost cost him his life.
The allegations cost me my job.
A late penalty cost United the game (= meant that they did not win the game).
Such behaviour could cost you your place in the team.
cost something The closure of the factory is likely to cost 1 000 jobs.
The war has cost the lives of countless civilians.

senses.definition: to involve you in making an effort or doing something unpleasant
examples: The accident cost me a visit to the doctor.

senses.definition: to estimate how much money will be needed for something or the price that should be charged for something
examples: cost something The project needs to be costed in detail.
fully costed proposals
cost something at something Their accountants have costed the project at $8.1 million.
cost something out Have you costed out these proposals yet?

senses.definition: to cost/pay a lot of money
to cost somebody a lot of money
examples: The campaign for the presidency has cost her dear.

senses.definition: to make somebody suffer a lot
examples: That one mistake has cost him dear over the years.

senses.definition: used to say that something will be expensive
examples: There is a deluxe model available, but it'll cost you.

senses.definition: the clothes worn by people from a particular place or during a particular historical period
examples: an exhibition of Victorian costumes
She wore a traditional costume of bright pink silk.
in… costume a painting of a woman in Welsh costume

senses.definition: the clothes worn by actors in a play or film, or worn by somebody to make them look like somebody/something else
examples: The former dancer has also designed the costumes.
The costumes for this production were gorgeous.
They are already planning their costumes for Halloween.
in a costume He went to the party in a giant chicken costume.
in costume The actors were still in costume and make-up.
She has four costume changes during the play.
a costume designer
For the dress rehearsal, the cast will be in full costume.
He designed the costumes for a production of ‘The Firebird’.
He had a cowboy costume on.
I have a great idea for my Halloween costume.
The battle was re-enacted by actors in period costume.
The main character had five costume changes.

senses.definition: a piece of clothing worn for swimming, especially the type worn by women and girls
examples: If you’d like a swim, we can lend you a costume.

senses.definition: a small house, especially in the country
examples: a thatched cottage
(British English) a holiday cottage
in a cottage James lived in a charming country cottage with roses around the door.
It was her dream to have a little cottage in the country
They built a small guest cottage on their land.
They lived in a tied cottage on the estate.
They put us up in a guest cottage next to their house.
We rented a cottage for a week.
We stayed in a cottage on a farm.
They rented a holiday cottage in the middle of nowhere.

senses.definition: a plant grown in warm countries for the soft white hairs around its seeds that are used to make cloth and thread
examples: They grew cotton, tobacco, corn and fruit.
bales of cotton
cotton fields/plantations/plants

senses.definition: the cloth made from the cotton plant
examples: The sheets are 100 per cent pure cotton.
a cotton shirt/skirt
printed cotton cloth
the cotton industry
a cotton mill
a pure cotton T-shirt
shivering in her thin cotton nightdress

senses.definition: thread that is used for sewing
examples: sewing cotton
a cotton reel

senses.definition: a soft mass of white material that is used for cleaning the skin or a wound
examples: Use a cotton ball to apply the lotion.

senses.definition: used as the past tense of ‘can’
examples: She said that she couldn't come.
I couldn't hear what they were saying.
Sorry, I couldn't get any more.
Can you play the piano?
I can hear someone calling.
The podcast can be downloaded here.
Can you/​are you able to come on Saturday?
You’ll be able to get a taxi outside the station.
I haven’t been able to get much work done today.
She’d love to be able to play the piano.
Our daughter could walk when she was nine months old.
I was able to/​managed to find some useful books in the library.
I could find some useful books in the library.
We weren’t able to/​didn’t manage to/​couldn’t get there in time.
I could see there was something wrong.
We could have won the game but decided to let them win.

senses.definition: used to ask if you can do something
examples: Could I use your phone, please?
Could we stop by next week?

senses.definition: used to politely ask somebody to do something for you
examples: Could you babysit for us on Friday?

senses.definition: used to show that something is or might be possible
examples: I could do it now, if you like.
Don't worry—they could have just forgotten to call.
You couldn't have left it on the bus, could you?
‘Have some more cake.’ ‘Oh, I couldn't, thank you (= I'm too full).’

senses.definition: used to suggest something
examples: We could write a letter to the director.

senses.definition: used to show that you are annoyed that somebody did not do something
examples: They could have let me know they were going to be late!

senses.definition: used to emphasize how strongly you want to express your feelings
examples: I'm so fed up I could scream!
He can speak three languages.
She will try and visit tomorrow.
You must find a job.
You ought to stop smoking.
I used to smoke but I gave up two years ago.
Can I invite Mary?
Should I have invited Mary?

senses.definition: used to say that you need or would like to have something
examples: I could do with a day off!
Her hair could have done with a wash.

senses.definition: a group of people who are elected to govern an area such as a city or county
examples: a town council

The council is/are voting on the proposals today.
on the council She's on the local council.
He won a seat on the council in a by-election.
She has served on the council for four years.
a member/meeting of the council
the leader of the council
a council member/leader
a council meeting/chamber

senses.definition: the organization that provides services in a city or county, for example education, houses, libraries, etc.
examples: Residents have complained to the council about the noise.
She has been working for the council since March.
Students should apply to their local council for a grant.
The council needs/need to address the traffic problem.
council workers/staff/officials/officers
cuts to council services

senses.definition: a group of people chosen to give advice, make rules, do research, provide money, etc.
examples: the Medical Research Council

There are plans to establish a funding council for higher education.
the governing council of the church
They are setting up a new council for the arts.
The Arts Council gives grants for local projects.

You should visit your local training and enterprise council.

senses.definition: (especially in the past) a formal meeting to discuss what action to take in a particular situation
examples: The king held a council at Nottingham from 14 to 19 October 1330.

senses.definition: an act of counting to find the total number of somebody/something
examples: If the election result is close, there will be a second count.
The bus driver did a quick count of the empty seats.
by somebody's count By my count there are eight tracks here that aren't on the band's three albums.

The vote count should be repeated.
We did a quick count of the children and there were none missing.

senses.definition: an act of saying numbers in order beginning with 1
examples: count of… Raise your leg and hold for a count of ten.

The referee didn't even finish the count when he saw that Juarez was unable to continue.
on a/the count of… On the count of three, take one step forward.

senses.definition: a measurement of the amount of something contained in a particular substance or area
examples: a raised white blood cell count
Her white cell count has gone down again.
an abnormally high white blood cell count

senses.definition: a crime that somebody is accused of committing
examples: They were found guilty on all counts.
to be charged with two counts of murder

senses.definition: a point made during a discussion or an argument
examples: I disagree with you on both counts.

senses.definition: a nobleman of high rank, similar to an earl in the UK
examples: Count Tolstoy

senses.definition: according to the latest information about the numbers of something
examples: She'd applied for 30 jobs at the last count.

senses.definition: to remember or keep a record of numbers or amounts of something over a period of time
examples: Keep a count of your calorie intake for one week.

senses.definition: to forget the total of something before you have finished counting it
examples: I lost count and had to start again.

I've lost count of the times I've heard that joke.

senses.definition: unable to get up again within ten seconds after being knocked down
in a deep sleep
to say numbers in the correct order
examples: Billy can't count yet.
count (up) to something She can count up to 10 in Italian.
count from something (to/up to something) to count from 1 to 10
He can now count from one to twenty.
We counted up to fifty, then set off to look for our friends.

senses.definition: to calculate the total number of people, things, etc. in a particular group
examples: count something (up) They're still counting votes in Texas.
I can't count the number of times I've eaten there (= I've eaten there very many times).
The diet is based on counting calories.
count (up) how many… She began to count up how many guests they had to invite.
count from… There are twelve weeks to go, counting from today.
She carefully counted the remaining coins and put them to one side.
We counted up our money.

senses.definition: to include somebody/something when you calculate a total
examples: We have invited 50 people, not counting the children.

senses.definition: to be important
examples: It is going to be a close election, so every vote counts.
Every point in this game counts.
With our busy lives today we have less and less time for what really counts.
It's the thought that counts (= used about a small but kind action or gift).
count for something The fact that she had apologized counted for nothing with him.

senses.definition: to be officially accepted; to accept something officially
examples: Don't go over that line or your throw won't count.

The home team's manager protested that the run should count.
count something Applications received after 1 July will not be counted.

senses.definition: to consider somebody/something in a particular way; to be considered in a particular way
examples: count (somebody/something) as somebody/something For tax purposes that money counts/is counted as income.

senses.definition: used to say that a total is continuing to increase
examples: The movie's ticket sales add up to $39 million, and counting.

senses.definition: used to say that the total number of somebody/something is very small
examples: She could count on the fingers of one hand the people she actually enjoyed being with.

senses.definition: to be grateful for the good things in your life

senses.definition: to imagine that sheep are jumping over a fence and to count them, as a way of getting to sleep

examples: Everyone needs to stand up and be counted in order to make them see the strength of our conviction.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not care how many times something happens
examples: I've seen the film five times, but who's counting?
